title-group.article-title: Factors associated with hospitalization of adult psychiatric patients: cluster analysis

contrib.aff: House Surgeon, Department of Psychological Medicine, Dunedin School of Medicine, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: Factors associated with acute admission to inpatient psychiatric wards have been difficult to replicate, possibly reflecting methodological limitations of analyzing individual variables. The objective of this analysis was to identify factors associated with hospitalization at an inpatient psychiatric unit using cluster analytic methods.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Demographic, admission and treatment data for all admissions to a single inpatient unit in 2010 were collected retrospectively. Cluster analysis was performed using Ward’s method.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The initial clustering identified a high suicidality/crisis group, which then gave two further subclusters, an internalizing one characterized by affective symptoms and an externalizing one characterized by intoxication at admission, and a population with poor medication compliance that included most cases of psychosis. These subclusters had different clinical and demographic characteristics, different rates of hospital readmission and different durations of stay.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Cluster analysis may be a useful exploratory technique to assist in planning and developing services for adult patients needing admission to a psychiatric hospital.

body.p: There are numerous studies evaluating factors associated with psychiatric hospitalization, especially for patients with frequent readmission and longer duration of stay.1–6 This is an important area of research, because of costs and resources associated with frequent readmission and longer hospital stay.7 However, it has been difficult to replicate findings across studies,8,9 which could reflect differences in patient populations, service availability or clinical practice. In addition, most studies have approached this research question through analysis of single variables, which may be a relatively insensitive approach to study the complex circumstances associated with admission and discharge from inpatient psychiatric services.

An alternative approach has been to use multivariate analysis methods to address this research question, using techniques such as cluster analysis and principal components analysis to identify patient subgroups associated with readmission, duration of admission or service use.7,8,10–13 While methodologically more robust, these studies have a number of limitations, including small numbers of patients studied,7,10 inclusion of patients admitted for the first time12,13 and clustering based on post-discharge service use patterns.11

The aim of this audit was to identify factors associated with admission and duration of stay at an inpatient psychiatric unit in a New Zealand city, with the intention of using these findings to review resource allocation and refine overall service provision.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This was a retrospective audit of all patients admitted to an acute open (unlocked) adult psychiatric unit between 1 January and 31 December 2010, in Dunedin, New Zealand. This ward has 16 beds, and serves a mixed urban/rural catchment of 193,800 (2006 census, Statistics New Zealand) people. In 2010, there were 555 admissions from 393 patients.

Data were obtained from hospital discharge summaries. If specific information was not mentioned in the summaries, patients’ hospital files were reviewed. Initial data collection was by ZW and YKC, with 100% data verification by PG. The following information was collected: demographics (age, gender); number of admissions and duration of admission(s); primary and key secondary DSM-IV14 diagnoses by category; legal status (requirement for compulsory admission under the NZ Mental Health Act); patient state at admission (suicidal, intoxicated, polysubstance use); whether the admission was associated with a crisis event or non-compliance with medication; treatment use while an inpatient; and follow-up arrangements (e.g. community psychiatric team; specialist psychotherapy clinic; alcohol and drugs clinic; youth psychiatric services, etc.) Treatment was categorized by medication class (antipsychotics, antidepressant, anxiolytic, mood stabilizer, medications for alcohol and drug treatment (e.g. methadone, naltrexone, disulfiram), and ECT. Quetiapine doses ≤ 150mg/day were classified as anxiolytic. As patients with more than one admission might also have longer total duration in hospital, the mean length of stay (LOS; total duration/ number of admissions) was determined for some analyses.

All analyses were performed on anonymized data sets. The relationships between duration of admission, diagnosis and other variables were assessed using Mann–Whitney U tests. Variables associated with more than one admission were assessed using the Pearson χ2 test or Fisher’s exact test. To evaluate combinations of variables associated with duration and number of admissions, a cluster analysis was performed. Cluster analysis is a set of techniques for data exploration. A hierarchical cluster analysis approach was used, in which successive clusters are derived from previously established clusters. Initial use of centroid and median methods gave crossovers in cluster groups, and average and weighted average methods gave unusual distributions, therefore Ward’s method was used. Output was assessed with a wide range of possible cluster numbers (2–50), and the final analysis included seven clusters. Variables in each cluster were identified by canonical linear discriminant analysis. Comparison of continuous data variables in each of the seven clusters (number of admissions, LOS and age) was assessed using one way analysis of variance; for significant results individual clusters were compared using the Sidak multiple range test. Stata version 11.0 was used for these analyses.

sec.title: Duration of admission
sec.p: Median (range) average duration of admission for all patients was seven (1–90) days. Numbers of patients with specific diagnoses are shown in Table 1, along with length of stay by diagnosis. Mean duration of admission was significantly longer for patients with bipolar disorder, and significantly shorter for patients with adjustment disorders and drug/alcohol dependence (Table 1).

caption.p: Median (range) average length of stay in hospital by primary DSM-IV diagnosis

fn.p: LOS: length of stay; NS: not significant

sec.p: Patients whose admissions were associated with a crisis event, or who presented as intoxicated or suicidal, had significantly shorter admissions than those without these features (Table 2). Patients who required admission under a Community Treatment Order (CTO), and those who were treated with mood stabilizers, antipsychotics or ECT had significantly longer hospital admissions than those who did not receive these interventions. At discharge, patients who were referred to a Community Mental Health Team had longer admissions than those who were not referred.

caption.p: Median (range) average length of stay in hospital by clinical presentation and treatment received

fn.p: LOS: length of stay; CTO: Community Treatment Order; ECT: electroconvulsive therapy

sec.title: Readmission
sec.p: In 2010, 294 patients had single admissions and 99 patients (25% of the total cohort) had 261 admissions (range 2–13). Patients who were readmitted were more likely to be female (1:>1 admission: 52% vs. 64%; p=0.04), to have a diagnosis of personality disorder (7% vs. 34%; p<0.0001) and to have a diagnosis of alcohol/drug dependence (13% vs. 26%; p=0.003). At admission, patients who were readmitted were more likely to be intoxicated (24% vs. 37%; p=0.01), to have polysubstance use (12% vs. 22%; p=0.009), to be suicidal (61% vs. 80%; p=0.0007), to be in crisis (48% vs. 60%; p=0.04), or to be noncompliant with medication (21% vs. 33%; p=0.01). During their hospital stay, patients who were readmitted were more likely to receive antianxiety medication (29% vs. 48%; p=0.0005), medication for alcohol/drug dependence (2% vs. 8%; p=0.02) or electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) (2% vs. 8%; p=0.02). At discharge, patients who were readmitted were more likely to be referred to day hospital or psychotherapy services (10% vs. 24%; p=0.0003), alcohol and drug treatment services (7% vs. 13%; p=0.05) or to be involved in a preventive admission scheme (0% vs. 11%; p<0.0001).

sec.title: Cluster analysis
sec.p: The final cluster analysis included seven clusters. Key variables associated with each cluster are listed in Table 3 and the dendrogram (Figure 1). The initial clustering was based on features associated with presentation, with one arm being associated with high rates of noncompliance and use of Community Treatment Orders and low rates of crisis and suicidality, the other arm having the opposite features. The low crisis/suicidality arm had one further cluster (psychosis cluster), which was related to diagnosis: cluster 1 with almost all patients with schizophrenia, and cluster 2 with mainly bipolar and schizoaffective disorder patients. The high crisis/suicidality arm had two subclusters. There was an internalizing cluster made up of patients with major depressive and anxiety disorders (cluster 3), a personality, anxiety and eating disorders cluster (4), with the highest proportion of females and highest rate of readmission, and a youth cluster (5), with high levels of anxiety and eating disorders. There was also an externalizing cluster made up predominantly of patients with drug and/or alcohol dependence (cluster 6) and patients with adjustment disorders (7). Duration of hospital admission was longest for the psychotic cluster (1 and 2), and shortest for the externalizing cluster (6 and 7).

caption.p: Clinical and demographic features of the seven patient clusters

tr.td: Diagnosis: 35/55 with PD, 16/48 with ANX, 7/15 with ED.
Diagnosis: 13/48 with ANX, 6/15 with ED; high proportion adolescent patients.

fn.p: # adm: number of admissions; AAnx: antianxiety medication; AD: antidepressant; ADJ: adjustment disorder; ANX: anxiety disorder; AP: antipsychotic medication; BAD: bipolar affective disorder; CTO: Community Treatment Order; D&A: drug and alcohol dependence; ED: eating disorder; %F: percent female; LOS: average length of stay; MDD: major depressive disorder; MS: mood stabilizer medication; PD: personality disorder; SAD: schizoaffective disorder; SCZ: schizophrenia

caption.p: ADJ: adjustment disorder; ANX: anxiety disorder; BAD: bipolar affective disorder; D&A: drug and alcohol dependence; ED: eating disorder; MDD: major depressive disorder; PD: personality disorder; SAD: schizoaffective disorder; SCZ: schizophrenia

sec.p: Significant differences were identified across clusters for patient age (F=20.6, df 6, 386, p<0.0001), number of admissions (F=12.6, df 6, 386, p<0.0001) and average length of stay (F=4.0, df 6, 386, p=0.0006). Mean age in cluster 2 (49.4 years) was significantly different from all other clusters (p<0.05 for all comparisons; Table 3), as was mean age in cluster 5 (21.0 years; p<0.01). Number of admissions in cluster 4 (2.5) was significantly different from all other clusters (p<0.001 for all comparisons; Table 3). Average LOS in cluster 7 (4.7 days) was significantly different from clusters 1 and 2 only (p<0.005 for both comparisons; see Table 3).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This audit identified multiple individual clinical and demographic factors associated with repeat admission and duration of hospital stay for general psychiatric inpatients. The cluster analysis provided a more comprehensive picture of clinical profiles associated with frequency of hospital admission and duration of hospital stay.

While the final clusters tended to separate into diagnostic categories, the initial division in the dendrogram was characterized by clinical features associated with admission, namely suicidality, crisis events and treatment noncompliance. The smaller subcluster from the initial division (n=124; 32%) had low levels of suicidality and crisis and higher levels of noncompliance; the larger subcluster (n=269; 68%) had high levels of suicidality and crisis and low levels of noncompliance (Figure 1). Rates of suicidality associated with admission in the entire cohort were high (66%), and are comparable to those reported in studies from Norway (50–62%),15,16 the UK (53%)17 and the Netherlands (58%),18 although lower rates have also been reported.19,20 Rates of crisis events prior to admission in the entire cohort were also high (51%). Prior studies have reported rates of hospitalization in response to a recent crisis event of between 17% and 44%18,21-23 and even higher rates if crises over the past 6–8 weeks are included (59–71%).24,25

The smaller subcluster, with low levels of suicidality and crisis and higher levels of noncompliance, yielded two further clusters, which included all patients with psychotic disorders, grouped into non-affective and affective psychoses (clusters 1 and 2; Figure 1). The larger subcluster, with high levels of suicidality and crisis and lower levels of noncompliance, yielded two subclusters (labeled as internalizing and externalizing). Clusters 6 and 7 (externalizing) had the highest proportion of patients with drug and alcohol dependence and adjustment disorder diagnoses, respectively, and were both characterized by the highest rates of crisis and intoxication at admission. A recent large US study26 described a patient group with similar characteristics, with high rates of suicidal ideation and relatively brief admissions. Adjustment disorders have not been included in the spectrum of externalizing disorders,27 but may have been included in this cluster because of high levels of intoxication associated with admission.

Patients in the internalizing cluster (clusters 3, 4 and 5) had high levels of mood disorder diagnoses (both depressive and anxious), with further differentiation based on presence of personality disorder and eating disorder diagnoses in adults (cluster 4) and adolescent patients (cluster 5). It is possible that further differentiation of this group could have been achieved had a greater number of clusters been studied. However, this could also reflect limitations in the nature and level of detail of data collection (see below).

There are a number of potential shortcomings in this report. Data collection was retrospective, and based on information in discharge summaries and clinical files. Although diagnoses were made by experienced clinicians, these were not based on structured interviews. Diagnoses were grouped (in particular, personality disorders and substance dependence disorders). Variables chosen for this analysis were based on a review of those reported in earlier studies.1–13 However, some variables that may predict readmission (e.g. previous hospital admission17 and illness severity5) were not collected. There are limitations inherent in the technique of cluster analysis, as it is an exploratory data tool. Finally, there may be limited applicability of these findings to inpatient populations in other locations, due to local differences in service provision, availability and clinical culture.

The present analysis of inpatient admissions to a general psychiatry ward over one year identified seven patient clusters, with different rates of hospital readmission and durations of stay, along with a range of other clinical and demographic characteristics. These findings may help guide service developments to reduce hospital admission and/or length of stay of a number of these clusters. Admissions due to lack of medication compliance (clusters 1 and 2) might be reduced by use of assertive community treatment approaches.28 Rates of hospitalization in clusters 6 and 7 might be reduced in two ways: because of high rates of crisis events, admission might be reduced by use of crisis resolution teams;24,25 and high rates of intoxication associated with admission might be better managed in an emergency department/acute diversion unit26 setting than by hospitalization. Frequency of admissions for some individuals with high rates of readmission in clusters 3, 4 and 5 (the internalizing cluster) may be managed through a pre-emptive admissions policy.29,30 It would be of interest to employ cluster analytic methods in other clinical inpatient settings to assess comparability of our findings.

ack.p: We appreciate the support of Ward 1a staff, in particular Susan Johnson and Mark Baldwin.

fn.label: Disclosure
fn.p: In the last three years, Professor Glue has been on the scientific advisory boards for Demerx Pharmaceuticals and Forrest Pharmaceuticals and on an advisory panel for Janssen-Cilag. No other authors have disclosures.
